title: David Ji
text: David Longfen Ji is an American businessman who co-founded Apex Digital, an electronics manufacturer.

title: David Ji
text: In 2004, he was arrested in China following a dispute with Sichuan Changhong Electric, a supplier owned by the city of Mianyang and the province of Sichuan.

title: David Ji
text: Changhong accused him of defrauding them through bad checks.

title: David Ji
text: Ji was taken, according to an account by his lawyer, to the senior management and told, "I decide whether you live or die."

title: David Ji
text: He has been held in China without charges.

title: David Ji
text: Ji's case highlighted an "implicit racism" in dealings with American businessmen.

title: David Ji
text: As a U.S. citizen he was not granted the same treatment by authorities as non-ethnically Chinese businessmen sharing the same nationality.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: Kirtland Kelsey Cutter( August 20, 1860 – September 26, 1939) was a 20th- century architect in the Pacific Northwest and California.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: He was born in East Rockport, Ohio, the great- grandson of Jared Potter Kirtland.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: He studied painting and illustration at the Art Students League of New York.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: At the age of 26 he moved to Spokane, Washington, and began working as a banker for his uncle.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: By the 1920s Cutter had designed several hundred buildings that established Spokane as a place rivaling Seattle and Portland, Oregon in its architectural quality.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: Most of Cutter's work is listed in State and National Registers of Historic Places.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: His design for the 1893 Chicago World's Fair Idaho Building was a rustic design log construction.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: It was a popular favorite, visited by an estimated 18 million people.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: The building's design and interior furnishings were a major precursor of the Arts and Crafts movement.

title: Kirtland Cutter
text: Cutter also worked in partnership with Karl G. Malmgren as Cutter& Malmgren and variations.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: Marc Ernest Elisabeth Robert Juliette Verwilghen, born 21 September 1952 in Dendermonde, is a Belgian politician.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: Verwilghen studied law at the Vrije Universiteit Brussel and the University of Ghent and is the holder of an honorary doctorate from Ghent.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: A member of the Flemish Liberals and Democrats( VLD), he was elected to the Belgian Chamber of Representatives in 1991 and 1995, and in 1999, to the Belgian Senate.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: In the Chamber he served as chairman of the Justice committee, and headed two special investigative committees into the events surrounding Marc Dutroux.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: He served as Justice minister from 1999 to 2003, as Development co-operation minister 2003 – 2004, and then as Minister of Economy( fully: Economy, Small and Medium Enterprises, the Middle Classes, Energy, Overseas Trade and Science) from 2004.

title: Marc Verwilghen
text: He was elected as a member of the Belgian Senate in 2007.

title: Joaquim Pimentel
text: (? in Cedofeita – 15 July 2003 in Lisbon) was a Portuguese Fado singer, who made his career as" ambassador" of the fado in Brazil, where he became popular and was called" the prince of Portuguese song."

title: Joaquim Pimentel
text: He first visited Brazil from 1934 to 1935, returned again to spend the war years in Brazil, and settled there permanently in 1947.

title: Jean-Denis Lejeune
text: Jean- Denis Lejeune( born 1959) is the father of Julie Lejeune, who was abducted along with Mélissa Russo in Belgium on 24 June 1995, and imprisoned in Marc Dutroux's cellar.

title: Jean-Denis Lejeune
text: She was eight years old at the time.

title: Jean-Denis Lejeune
text: She died, probably of starvation, sometime between 6 December 1995 and 20 March 1996.

title: Jean-Denis Lejeune

title: Sabine Dardenne
text: Sabine Anne Renée Ghislaine Dardenne( born 28 October 1983) is a Belgian author.

title: Sabine Dardenne
text: She was kidnapped at the age of twelve by the child molester and serial killer Marc Dutroux in 1996.

title: Sabine Dardenne
text: Dardenne was one of Dutroux's last two victims.

title: Sabine Dardenne
text: She and fellow captive Laetitia Delhez survived, though the bodies of four other kidnap victims and Dutroux's accomplice were found on the property.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Marc Paul Alain Dutroux( born 6 November 1956) is a Belgian convicted child molester and murderer.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Dutroux was convicted in 1989 for the abduction and rape of five young girls( with his then- wife Michelle Martin) and other accomplices.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: He was released on parole after three years in prison.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: In 1996, Dutroux was arrested on suspicion of having kidnapped, tortured and sexually abused six females aged between 8 and 19, four of whom died.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: His widely publicised trial took place in 2004.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Dutroux was convicted of all charges, along with the murder of a suspected former accomplice, and sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Martin was convicted as an accomplice to 30 years in prison.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Another accomplice Michele Lièvre was convicted to 25 years in prison.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Michel Nihoul was first trialed with Marc Dutroux but then convicted in a separate case to five years in prison.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: Another accomplice of Marc Dutroux, Bernard Weinstein, was killed by him and thus never trialed.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: A number of shortcomings in the Dutroux investigation caused widespread discontent in Belgium with the country's criminal justice system, and the ensuing scandal was one of the reasons for the reorganisation of Belgium's law enforcement agencies and widespread allegations of corruption and infiltration of the Belgian justice system by a criminal enterprise.

title: Marc Dutroux
text: In the White March, 300,000 Belgian citizens protested the mishandling of the case.

title: Nestor Pirotte
text: He was sentenced for murdering three people, in addition to being suspected of four other murders.

text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.

text: What is Money?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: Philip Ives Dunne (February 11, 1908 – June 2, 1992) was a Hollywood screenwriter, film director and producer, who worked prolifically from 1932 until 1965.

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: He spent the majority of his career at 20th Century Fox crafting well regarded romantic and historical dramas, usually adapted from another medium.

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: Dunne was a leading Screen Writers Guild organizer and was politically active during the "Hollywood Blacklist" episode of the 1940s-1950s.

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: He is best known for the films

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: "How Green Was My Valley" (1941), "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir" (1947), "The Robe" (1953) and "The Agony and the Ecstasy" (1965).

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: Dunne received two Academy Award nominations for screenwriting: "

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: How Green Was My Valley" (1941) and "David and Bathsheba" (1951).

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: He also received a Golden Globe nomination for his 1965 screen adaptation of Irving Stone's novel "The Agony and the Ecstasy", as well as several peer awards from the Writers Guild of America (WGA), including the Laurel Award for Screenwriting Achievement.

title: Philip Dunne (writer)
text: Many notable directors worked with Dunne's screenplays, including Carol Reed, John Ford, Jacques Tourneur, Elia Kazan, Otto Preminger, Joseph L. Mankiewicz, and Michael Curtiz, among others.

title: Laali
text: Laali is a 1997 Indian Kannada drama film directed, written and scripted by Dinesh Babu, starring Vishnuvardhan, Mohini and Shanthi Krishna in the lead roles.

title: Laali
text: The film was produced by Rockline Venkatesh under his home production, Rockline Productions.

title: Laali
text: The film was critically acclaimed upon release and won laurels at the Karnataka State Film Awards.

title: Laali
text: While the film won the Second Best Film award, the lead actor Vishnuvardhan was adjudged the Best Actor for the year 1997.

title: Laali
text: The music composed by V. Manohar was also received positively.

title: Laali
text: It is considered one of the finest movies ever made by Dinesh Babu.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: Love is the title of both a 2010 short film and a 2012 feature- length film.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: Both films were directed and written by Travis Mathews.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: The drama films both revolve around the friends and ex-lovers of Jesse Metzger, a gay man in his mid-thirties who is forced to move back to his hometown from San Francisco due to financial reasons.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: The actors' own names, along with much of their real- life stories, were used for their characters in both films, which features graphic sexual scenes.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: The production of both films was aided by the gay pornographic studio NakedSword.

title: I Want Your Love (film)
text: This led to the full- length film being refused exemption from classification, which would have allowed it to screen at the Melbourne Queer Film Festival, a decision to which actor James Franco( who invited Mathews to collaborate on Franco's film" Interior. Leather Bar.") reacted negatively.

title: Albert Pyun
text: Albert Pyun (born May 19, 1953) is an American film director best known for having made many low-budget B-movies and direct-to-video action films.

title: Albert Pyun
text: The Independent Film Channel said that Pyun "has carved out a unique niche as a director of low-budget, high-concept genre films starring actors past their prime", adding that "others believe this a charitable description for Pyun, who has also been derided as the new Ed Wood.

title: Albert Pyun
text: " Though he frequently blends kickboxing and hybrid martial arts with science fiction and dystopic or post-apocalyptic themes, which often include cyborgs, Pyun stated in an interview that "I have really no interest in cyborgs.

title: Albert Pyun
text: And I've never really had any interest in post-apocalyptic stories or settings.

title: Albert Pyun
text: It just seemed that those situations presented a way for me to make movies with very little money, and to explore ideas that I really wanted to explore — even if they were ."

title: Albert Pyun
text: Some of Pyun's better known films include "The Sword and the SorcererCyborgCaptain America", and "Nemesis".

title: Albert Pyun
text: Pyun was a military brat and lived on bases around the world until his father settled in Hawaii.

title: Albert Pyun
text: Pyun went to school in Kailua, a small town located on the windward side of Oahu.

title: Albert Pyun
text: Pyun's first 8mm and 16mm movies were made in Kailua and he credits living in foreign countries and growing up in Hawaii as strong influences on his filmmaking style.

title: William Berke
text: Richard Fleischer later recalled Berke" was known as King of the B's.

title: William Berke
text: For years and years he had made nothing but pictures with ten or twelve day shooting schedules, minuscule budgets of about$ 100,000 and no stars.

title: William Berke
text: Without bothering with editing or any postproduction chores and with short shooting schedules, he was able to squeeze in eight or ten pictures a year.

title: William Berke
text: And he was going nuts".

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: 3 Indian Tales is a Canadian docufiction film, directed by Robert Morin and released in 2014.

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: Using a cast of non-professional actors, the film tells three stories of First Nations youth: Erik wants to open a community television station, Shayne listens to classical music as he travels to a mining site, Shandy-Ève and Marie-Claude pray to Saint Kateri Tekakwitha.

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: Morin made the film with the goal of encouraging viewers to reconsider their prejudices of First Nations by dramatizing the stories of real youth who are not falling into the stereotypes, but instead are engaged and ambitious.

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: He shot the film with indigenous youth from the Kitcisakik and Lac-Simon reserves in the Abitibi-Témiscamingue region of Quebec.

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: The film premiered at the 2014 Berlin Film Festival.

title: 3 Indian Tales
text: The film received five Prix Jutra nominations at the 17th Jutra Awards, for Best Film, Best Director (Morin), Best Screenplay (Morin), Best Sound (Morin, Bruno Bélanger, Louis Collin, Bernard Gariépy Strobl) and Best Editing (Michel Giroux).

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

text: His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.

title: Etan Boritzer

text: What is Funny?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Money?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Dreaming?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Friend?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is True?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Family?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Feeling?"

text: The series is now also translated into 15 languages.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Etan Boritzer

text: Moving to Buenos Aires at a young age, Tinayre directed some 23 films between 1934 and 1974, directing films such as the 1947 thriller "A sangre fría" (In Cold Blood) which starred actors such as Amelia Bence and Tito Alonso.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: He was also an acclaimed screenwriter and producer simultaneously contributing in these areas to the films he directed in Argentine cinema.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: In 1949 he directed "Dance of Fire", which was later entered into the 1951 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: His 1960 film "La patota" was entered into the 11th Berlin International Film Festival.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: His 1963 film "

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: The Dragonfly Is Not an Insect" was entered into the 3rd Moscow International Film Festival.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: In 1969 he directed "Kuma Ching"; his last film was to be "La Mary" (1974), starring then-couple Susana Giménez and boxer Carlos Monzón.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: He died in 1994.

title: Daniel Tinayre
text: His widow was the well-known actress and television host Mirtha Legrand.

title: A Hill in Korea
text: A Hill in Korea is a 1956 British war film based on Max Catto's 1953 novel of the same name.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: First Hill is a neighborhood in Seattle, Washington, named for the hill on which it is located.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: The hill, in turn, is so named for being the first hill one encounters traveling east from downtown Seattle toward Lake Washington.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: First Hill is bounded on the west by Interstate 5, beyond which is Downtown, on the north by E. Pike and E. Madison Streets, beyond which is Capitol Hill, and on the south by S. Main St., beyond which is the International District.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: The City of Seattle provides conflicting information about its eastern limit, beyond which are Cherry Hill and the Central District.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: Some describe it as being bounded by Broadway and Boren Avenues, while others describe it as being bounded by 12th Avenue.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: First Hill rose to popularity in the 1890s as a location close enough to downtown for convenience, but far enough out to offer a sense of retreat for the wealthier residents of Seattle.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: Among the elite to live on First Hill at that time were Indian fighter turned wealthy businessman Granville O. Haller, local judge Cornelius H. Hanford, successful meatpacker Charles Frye (whose private art collection is now open to the public at First Hill's Frye Art Museum), contractor Morgan Carkeek (for whom Carkeek Park is named), William Boeing, founder of the Boeing Company and Judge Hiram Bond.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: Noted photographer Imogen Cunningham and her husband Roi Partridge lived on First Hill in a boarding house in the 1910s until the residents of the house were evicted and the property converted into a hospital.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: More recently, local philanthropist and businesswoman Patsy Bullitt Collins resided in a First Hill condominium.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: The first official King County Courthouse was built on First Hill in 1889–1890; the steep climb to the courthouse from downtown legal offices caused such frequent and vociferous complaints that Seattle lawyers nicknamed the area "Profanity Hill".

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: The courthouse, constructed on the corner of 7th Avenue and Alder Street, was quickly outgrown, which, along with the loud dissatisfaction of local attorneys, led the county to move the courthouse off First Hill in 1916.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: The hill is also known as "Pill Hill" because, in addition to being the current home of three major health care facilities (Harborview Medical Center, Swedish Medical Center/First Hill, and Virginia Mason Medical Center (four if Swedish Medical Center/Cherry Hill, located on 16th Avenue, is included in the neighborhood)), as well as the Puget Sound Blood Center, it was also once the location of the Maynard, Seattle General, and Doctors Hospitals (all of which merged into Swedish) as well as Cabrini Hospital.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: First Hill has been home to Seattle University, a private Jesuit university, since 1891.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: Also located on the hill are Northwest School and Seattle Academy of Arts and Sciences—two highly regarded private schools—and the Catholic O'Dea High School, Frye Art Museum, as well as several churches that have become city landmarks: Trinity Parish Church, St. James Cathedral, and Seattle First Baptist Church.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: First Hill's major thoroughfares, assuming its greatest possible extent (see above), include Madison, James, Cherry, and Jefferson Streets and Yesler Way (east- and west-bound) and 9th, Boren, and Broadway (north- and south-bound).

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: A Link Light Rail station was originally planned for First Hill, but was cancelled due to geotechnical risks prior to the construction of University Link.

title: First Hill, Seattle
text: Instead, the First Hill Streetcar was built on Broadway and Jackson Street to connect First Hill with the International District / Chinatown and Capitol Hill stations after it opened in 2016.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: The First Hill Streetcar, officially the First Hill Line, is a streetcar route in Seattle, Washington, United States, forming part of the modern Seattle Streetcar system.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: It travels between several neighborhoods in central Seattle, including the International District, First Hill, and Capitol Hill.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: The line has ten stops and runs primarily in mixed traffic on South Jackson Street and Broadway.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: The streetcar line was proposed in 2005 as an alternative to a cancelled Link light rail station on First Hill, with the goal of connecting the neighborhood to other light rail stations.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: The$ 135 million project, funded primarily by Sound Transit, was approved by voters and the city council in 2008.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: The city government selected the Broadway corridor and began construction on the line in April 2012, also working on a parallel protected bicycle lane.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: Construction was completed in late 2014, but delays in the delivery and testing of the streetcar vehicles pushed the opening of the line to January 23, 2016.

title: First Hill Streetcar
text: A proposed connection to the South Lake Union Streetcar line was planned to be constructed in the late 2010s, but was suspended by the city government in 2018.

title: Ek Anek Aur Ekta

title: Vijaya Mulay
text: Vijaya Mulay( 16 May 1921 – 19 May 2019) was a documentary filmmaker, film historian, writer, educationist and researcher.

title: Vijaya Mulay
text: Her close friendships with Satyajit Ray, Louis Malle, Mrinal Sen and other film personalities gave her a unique perspective into Indian cinema and influenced her work.

title: Vijaya Mulay
text: Her body of work has shaped how India is viewed by Indian and non-Indian filmmakers.

title: Vijaya Mulay
text: She is the mother of National Award winning actor Suhasini Mulay and Atul Gurtu the high energy physicist is her son-in- law.

title: Vijaya Mulay
text: Vijaya Mulay is remembered for her animation film" Ek Anek Aur Ekta" which won the National Film Award for Best Educational Film.

title: Indian animation industry
text: The Indian animation industry encompasses traditional 2D animation, 3D animation and visual effects for feature films.

title: Indian animation industry
text: In 1956, Disney Studios animator Clair Weeks, who had worked on" Bambi", was invited to Films Division of India in Mumbai to establish and train the country's first animation studio as part of the American technical co-operation mission.

title: Indian animation industry
text: He trained a core group of Indian animators, whose first production was a film called" The Banyan Deer"( 1957).

title: Indian animation industry
text: Veteran animator Ram Mohan started his career at Films Division's Cartoon Unit.

title: Indian animation industry
text: Another landmark animated film from Films Division is" Ek Anek Aur Ekta", a short traditionally animated educational film released in 1974.

title: Indian animation industry
text: The film is presented as a fable meant to teach children the value of unity, and was frequently broadcast on India's state- run television station, Doordarshan.

title: Indian animation industry
text: The first Indian animated television series was" Ghayab Aaya", which aired in 1986 and was directed by Suddhasattwa Basu.

title: Indian animation industry
text: The first Indian 3D and VFX were done for the television series" Captain Vyom" by animation.

title: Indian animation industry
text: The first Indian 3D animated film was" Roadside Romeo", a joint venture between Yash Raj Films and the Indian division of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Indian animation industry

title: Kiss the Blood Off My Hands
text: Kiss the Blood Off My Hands is a 1948 American film noir crime film directed by Norman Foster starring Burt Lancaster, Joan Fontaine and Robert Newton based on a novel of the same name by Gerald Bulter.

title: Kiss the Blood Off My Hands
text: It was the first film made by Hecht and Lancaster's production company, Norma Productions.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Gerald Butler( July 31, 1907 – February 1, 1988) was an English crime, mystery, thriller and pulp writer and screenwriter.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He was born on July 31, 1907 and worked as a chemist prior to becoming a novelist.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He later worked as a director of an advertising firm.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He was sometimes referred to as the English James M. Cain.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He was thirty- three years old when his first novel," Kiss the Blood Off My Hands", was published in 1940 by Jarrolds Publishing.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: " Kiss the Blood Off My Hands" became a best- seller and by 1945, it had sold over 232,000 copies in England alone( all during war- time).

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: In 1945, American publishers Farrar& Rinehart, were the first to publish one of Butler's novels outside of England.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Their first release of Butler's work was his 1943 novel," Their Rainbow Had Black Edges", issued under the title" Dark Rainbow".

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Farrar& Rinehart went on to publish four more of his novels for the American market, between 1946 and 1951.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Following the publication of his first four novels, Eagle- Lion Films bought the film rights to" Kiss the Blood Off My Hands" in 1946, hoping to turn it into a Robert Donat film.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: After the option expired, the novel's film rights were sold to actor- turned- producer Burt Lancaster and his business partner Harold Hecht in mid-1947.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: The film was the first project for Lancaster's new production company, Norma Productions, and hit the screens in October 1948.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: The film starred Joan Fontaine, Burt Lancaster and Robert Newton and was released in some markets under the names" The Unafraid" or" Blood on My Hands", due to censor issues.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Meanwhile, producer/ director Mario Zampi approached Butler in 1947 to collaborate on a film noir thriller," The Fatal Night".

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Butler adapted Michael Arlen's famous short story," The Gentleman From America" into a screenplay for the film which was released in April 1948.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: Butler and Zampi collaborated again a year later for the Zampi- produced" Third Time Lucky", Butler's screen adaptation of his own novel" They Cracked Her Glass Slipper".

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: The film was released in January 1949 and was directed by Gordon Parry.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: A third Butler novel was turned into a film," Mad with Much Heart", released as" On Dangerous Ground".

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: It starred Ida Lupino( who was also an uncredited director) and Robert Ryan and was directed by Nicholas Ray.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: This last film adaption was released in 1951, the same year that Butler's sixth novel," Blow Hot, Blow Cold", was published.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He withdrew from the writing industry for nearly twenty years before returning with his last novel," There Is a Death, Elizabeth", published in 1972.

title: Gerald Butler (author)
text: He died sixteen years later.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The other current books in the" What is?" series include

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Love?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Death?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Beautiful?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Funny?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Right?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Peace?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Money?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Dreaming?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Friend?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is True?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Family?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Feeling?"

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The series is now also translated into 15 languages.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

title: Iconic (song)
text: "Iconic" is a song recorded by American singer and songwriter Madonna for her thirteenth studio album "Rebel Heart" (2015).

title: Iconic (song)
text: It was written by Madonna, Toby Gad, Maureen McDonald, Larry Griffin Jr., Chancelor Bennett, Dacoury Natche and Michael Tucker.

title: Iconic (song)
text: "Iconic" was produced by Madonna, Gad, AFSHeeN and Josh Cumbee, while DJ Dahi and Tucher served as additional producers.

title: Iconic (song)
text: It features American rapper Chance

title: Iconic (song)
text: the Rapper and a spoken intro by American professional boxer Mike Tyson.

title: Iconic (song)
text: The song's demo was leaked onto the internet on December 17, 2014, alongside twelve other tracks from the album, with "Iconic" also being rumored as the album's title.

title: Iconic (song)
text: Its final version was released on February 9, 2015, with "Hold Tight" and "Joan of Arc", on the iTunes store.

title: Iconic (song)
text: A trap-influenced EDM song, "Iconic" features in its instrumentation "ice-cold" synths, marching drums and "booming" bass, as well as machinic stabs and electronic gears.

title: Iconic (song)
text: Lyrically, the song encourages people to take control of their life, to pursue their dreams and to find their own greatness.

title: Iconic (song)
text: The song received generally favorable reviews from critics, who praised the song's "weird" beat and odd collaboration, recognizing its catchiness.

title: Iconic (song)
text: Although, some criticized Tyson's addition and were confused with the song's message.

title: Iconic (song)
text: It charted in some European territories, peaking inside the top-forty in Finland, Hungary and Spain.

title: Iconic (song)
text: Madonna performed the track as the opening number of the Rebel Heart Tour (2015–16).

title: Iconic (song)
text: During the performance, she is inside a medieval-looking cage in a kimono-like robe, with her dancers being dressed as gladiators.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Madonna Louise Ciccone (born August 16, 1958) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and businesswoman.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Referred to as the "Queen of Pop" since the 1980s, Madonna is known for pushing the boundaries of songwriting in mainstream popular music and for the imagery she uses onstage and in music videos.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: She has frequently reinvented her music and image while maintaining autonomy within the recording industry.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Her works have been praised by music critics and have sparked controversy.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Madonna is often cited as an influence by other artists.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Born and raised in Michigan, Madonna moved to New York City in 1978 to pursue a career in modern dance.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: After performing as a drummer, guitarist, and vocalist in the rock bands Breakfast Club and Emmy, Madonna signed with Sire Records in 1982 and released her eponymous debut album the next year.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: She followed it with a series of successful albums, including global bestsellers "Like a Virgin" (1984) and "True Blue" (1986) as well as Grammy Award winners "Ray of Light" (1998) and "Confessions on a Dance Floor" (2005).

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Many of her songs have reached the top of record charts worldwide, including "Like a VirginLa Isla BonitaLike a PrayerVogueTake a BowFrozenMusicHung Up", and "4 Minutes".

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Madonna's popularity was further enhanced by her roles in films such as "Desperately Seeking Susan" (1985), "Dick Tracy" (1990), "A League of Their Own" (1992), and "Evita" (1996).

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: While "Evita" earned her a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress, many of her other films received poor reviews.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: As a businesswoman, Madonna founded an entertainment company called Maverick (including the label Maverick Records) in 1992.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Her other ventures include fashion design, children's books, health clubs, and filmmaking.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: She contributes to various charities, having founded Ray of Light Foundation in 1998 and Raising Malawi in 2006.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Having sold more than 300 million records worldwide, Madonna is noted as the best-selling female recording artist of all time by "Guinness World Records".

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: The Recording Industry Association of America listed her as the third highest-certified female artist in the U.S., with 64.5 million album units.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: According to "Billboard", Madonna is the most successful solo artist in its Hot 100 chart history.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: She is also the highest-grossing solo touring artist of all time, accumulating U.S. $1.4 billion from her concert tickets.

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in her first year of eligibility, Madonna topped VH1's countdown of 100 Greatest Women in Music. "

title: Madonna (entertainer)
text: Rolling Stone" listed her among the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time and the 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time.

title: Miss Lovely
text: Miss Lovely is a 2012 Indian drama film directed by Ashim Ahluwalia and set in the criminal depths of Mumbai's C-grade( horror and porn film) industry.

title: Miss Lovely
text: Ahluwalia's debut feature follows the story of the Duggal brothers who produce sleazy sex- horror films in the mid-1980s.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The plot explores the intense and mutually destructive relationship between younger sibling Sonu Duggal, played by Nawazuddin Siddiqui, and his elder brother, Vicky( Anil George).

title: Miss Lovely
text: Sonu finds himself drawn to a mysterious young woman named Pinky( Niharika Singh) eventually leading to his downfall.

title: Miss Lovely
text: " Miss Lovely" had its cinematic release on 17 January 2014.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The film has received the National Film Award – Special Jury Award( Feature film) and Best Production Design at the 61st National Film Awards.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The stylized form, densely layered narrative, period costumes and production design simultaneously conveys a pulp style and contemporaneous modernity.

title: Miss Lovely
text: Jonathan Romney of Sight& Sound described the film as" A shock to the system – an Indian film like I ’d never seen."

title: Miss Lovely
text: The film constantly switches between genre pieces and is part hard- boiled film noir, part love story, part melodrama and part documentary.

title: Miss Lovely
text: It has been compared to Rainer Werner Fassbinder ’s" The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant", and Wong Kar Wai's" Chungking Express".

title: Miss Lovely
text: Shot on a combination of Kodak Super 16 and 35 mm film in widescreen, central themes of Miss Lovely include repressed sexuality, censorship, the deconstruction of genre, the material nature of celluloid and the extinction of cinema itself.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The film soundtrack also links back to a history of past cinema, particularly the use of rare work of Italian composers Egisto Macchi and Piero Umiliani, who had both scored exploitation films.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The soundtrack also employs film scores by Indian composer Ilaiyaraaja and disco producer Biddu.

title: Miss Lovely
text: Miss Lovely competed in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2012 Cannes Film Festival.

title: Miss Lovely
text: The film has since screened at numerous film festivals including the Toronto International Film Festival and International Film Festival Rotterdam.

title: Miss Lovely
text: Miss Lovely had release of around 300 screens in India on 17 January 2014.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: Good Will Hunting is a 1997 American drama film directed by Gus Van Sant, and starring Robin Williams, Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Minnie Driver, and Stellan Skarsgård.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: Written by Affleck and Damon, the film follows 20-year-old South Boston janitor Will Hunting, an unrecognized genius who, as part of a deferred prosecution agreement after assaulting a police officer, becomes a client of a therapist and studies advanced mathematics with a renowned professor.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: Through his therapy sessions, Will re-evaluates his relationships with his best friend, his girlfriend, and himself, facing the significant task of confronting his past and thinking about his future.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: The film grossed over $225 million during its theatrical run, from a $10 million budget.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: It was nominated for nine Academy Awards, including the Academy Award for Best Picture, and won two: Best Supporting Actor for Williams and Best Original Screenplay for Affleck and Damon.

title: Good Will Hunting
text: In 2014, it was ranked at number 53 in "The Hollywood Reporter"s "100 Favorite Films" list.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: Gus Green Van Sant Jr. (born July 24, 1952) is an American film director, screenwriter, painter, photographer, musician, and author who has earned acclaim as both an independent and mainstream filmmaker.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: His films typically deal with themes of marginalized subcultures, in particular homosexuality; as such, Van Sant is considered one of the most prominent auteurs of the New Queer Cinema movement.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: Van Sant's early career was devoted to directing television commercials in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: He made his feature-length cinematic directorial debut with "Mala Noche" (1985).

title: Gus Van Sant
text: His second feature "Drugstore Cowboy" (1989) was highly acclaimed, and earned Van Sant screenwriting awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association and New York Film Critics Circle and the award for Best Director from the National Society of Film Critics.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: His following film, "My Own Private Idaho" (1991), was similarly praised, as was the black comedy "To Die For" (1995), the drama "Good Will Hunting" (1997), and the biographical film "Milk" (2008); for the latter two, Van Sant was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Director and both films received Best Picture nominations.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: In 2003, Van Sant's film about the Columbine High School massacre, "Elephant", won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: Van Sant also received the festival's Best Director Award that same year, making him one of only two filmmakers—the other being Joel Coen—to win both accolades at the festival in the same year.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: Though most of Van Sant's other films received favourable reviews, such as "Finding Forrester" (2000) and "Paranoid Park" (2007), some of his efforts, such as the art house production "Last Days" (2005) and the environmental drama "Promised Land" (2012), have received more mixed reviews from critics, while his adaptation of Tom Robbins's "Even Cowgirls Get the Blues" (1994), his 1998 remake of Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho", and "The Sea of Trees" (2015), were critical and commercial failures.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: In addition to directing, Van Sant has written the screenplays for several of his earlier works, and is the author of a novel entitled "Pink".

title: Gus Van Sant
text: A book of his photography, called "108 Portraits", has also been published, and he has released two musical albums.

title: Gus Van Sant
text: He is openly gay and currently lives in Los Feliz, California.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Bob Dylan (born Robert Allen Zimmerman; May 24, 1941) is an American singer-songwriter, author, and visual artist who has been a major figure in popular culture for more than fifty years.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Much of his most celebrated work dates from the 1960s, when songs such as "Blowin' in the Wind" (1963) and "The Times They Are a-Changin'" (1964) became anthems for the civil rights movement and anti-war movement.

title: Bob Dylan
text: His lyrics during this period incorporated a wide range of political, social, philosophical, and literary influences, defied pop-music conventions and appealed to the burgeoning counterculture.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Following his self-titled debut album in 1962, which mainly comprised traditional folk songs, Dylan made his breakthrough as a songwriter with the release of "The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan" the following year.

title: Bob Dylan
text: The album featured "Blowin' in the Wind" and the thematically complex "A Hard Rain's a-Gonna Fall."

title: Bob Dylan
text: For many of these songs, he adapted the tunes and phraseology of older folk songs.

title: Bob Dylan
text: He went on to release the politically charged "The Times They Are a-Changin'" and the more lyrically abstract and introspective "Another Side of Bob Dylan" in 1964.

title: Bob Dylan
text: In 1965 and 1966, Dylan encountered controversy when he adopted electrically amplified rock instrumentation, and in the space of 15 months recorded three of the most important and influential rock albums of the 1960s: "Bringing It All Back Home" (1965), "Highway 61 Revisited" (1965) and "Blonde on Blonde" (1966).

title: Bob Dylan
text: The six-minute single "Like a Rolling Stone" (1965) has been described as challenging and transforming the "artistic conventions of its time, for all time."

title: Bob Dylan
text: In July 1966, Dylan withdrew from touring after being injured in a motorcycle accident.

title: Bob Dylan
text: During this period, he recorded a large body of songs with members of the Band, who had previously backed him on tour.

title: Bob Dylan
text: These recordings were released as the collaborative album "The Basement Tapes" in 1975.

title: Bob Dylan
text: In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Dylan explored country music and rural themes in "John Wesley Harding" (1967), "Nashville Skyline" (1969), and "New Morning" (1970).

title: Bob Dylan
text: In 1975, he released "Blood on the Tracks", which many saw as a return to form.

title: Bob Dylan
text: In the late 1970s, he became a born-again Christian and released a series of albums of contemporary gospel music before returning to his more familiar rock-based idiom in the early 1980s.

title: Bob Dylan
text: The major works of his later career include "Time Out of Mind" (1997), "Love and Theft" (2001), "Modern Times" (2006) and "Tempest" (2012).

title: Bob Dylan
text: His most recent recordings have comprised versions of traditional American standards, especially songs recorded by Frank Sinatra.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Backed by a changing lineup of musicians, he has toured steadily since the late 1980s on what has been dubbed the Never Ending Tour.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Since 1994, Dylan has published eight books of drawings and paintings, and his work has been exhibited in major art galleries.

title: Bob Dylan
text: He has sold more than 100 million records, making him one of the best-selling music artists of all time.

title: Bob Dylan
text: He has also received numerous awards, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, ten Grammy Awards, a Golden Globe Award, and an Academy Award.

title: Bob Dylan
text: Dylan has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Minnesota Music Hall of Fame, Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame, and the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

title: Bob Dylan
text: The Pulitzer Prize Board in 2008 awarded him a special citation for "his profound impact on popular music and American culture, marked by lyrical compositions of extraordinary poetic power."

title: Bob Dylan
text: In 2016, Dylan was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature "for having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition."

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Sergei Parajanov( sometimes spelled Paradzhanov or Paradjanov; January 9, 1924 – July 20, 1990) was a Soviet film director and artist of Armenian descent who made significant contributions to Soviet cinematography through Ukrainian, Georgian, and Armenian cinema.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: He invented his own cinematic style, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism( the only sanctioned art style in the USSR).

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: This, combined with his controversial lifestyle and behaviour, led Soviet authorities to repeatedly persecute and imprison him, and suppress his films.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Although he started professional film- making in 1954, Parajanov later disowned all the films he made before 1965 as" garbage".

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: After directing" Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors"( renamed" Wild Horses of Fire" for most foreign distributions)

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Parajanov became something of an international celebrity and simultaneously a target of attacks from the system.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Nearly all of his film projects and plans from 1965 to 1973 were banned, scrapped or closed by the Soviet film administrations, both local( in Kiev and Yerevan) and federal( Goskino), almost without discussion, until he was finally arrested in late 1973 on charges of rape, homosexuality and bribery.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: He was imprisoned until 1977, despite a pleas for pardon from various artists.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Even after his release( he was arrested for the third and last time in 1982) he was a" persona non grata" in Soviet cinema.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: It was not until the mid-1980s, when the political climate started to relax, that he could resume directing.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Still, it required the help of influential Georgian actor Dodo Abashidze and other friends to have his last feature films greenlighted.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: His health seriously weakened by four years in labor camps and nine months in prison in Tbilisi, Parajanov died of lung cancer in 1990, at a time when, after almost 20 years of suppression, his films were being featured at foreign film festivals.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: In January 1988, he said in an interview," Everyone knows that I have three Motherlands.

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: I was born in Georgia, worked in Ukraine and I'm going to die in Armenia."

title: Sergei Parajanov
text: Sergei Parajanov is buried at Komitas Pantheon in Yerevan.

title: Sergei Parajanov

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Béla IV (1206 – 3 May 1270) was King of Hungary and Croatia between 1235 and 1270, and Duke of Styria from 1254 to 1258.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: As the oldest son of King Andrew II, he was crowned upon the initiative of a group of influential noblemen in his father's lifetime in 1214.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: His father, who strongly opposed Béla's coronation, refused to give him a province to rule until 1220.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: In this year, Béla was appointed Duke of Slavonia, also with jurisdiction in Croatia and Dalmatia.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Around the same time, Béla married Maria, a daughter of Theodore

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: I Laskaris, Emperor of Nicaea.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: From 1226, he governed Transylvania with the title Duke.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He supported Christian missions among the pagan Cumans who dwelled in the plains to the east of his province.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Some Cuman chieftains acknowledged his suzerainty and he adopted the title of King of Cumania in 1233.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: King Andrew died on 21 September 1235 and Béla succeeded him.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He attempted to restore royal authority, which had diminished under his father.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: For this purpose, he revised his predecessors' land grants and reclaimed former royal estates, causing discontent among the noblemen and the prelates.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: The Mongols invaded Hungary and annihilated Béla's army in the Battle of Mohi on 11 April 1241.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He escaped from the battlefield, but a Mongol detachment chased him from town to town as far as Trogir on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Although he survived the invasion, the Mongols devastated the country before their unexpected withdrawal in March 1242.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Béla introduced radical reforms in order to prepare his kingdom for a second Mongol invasion.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He allowed the barons and the prelates to erect stone fortresses and to set up their private armed forces.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He promoted the development of fortified towns.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: During his reign, thousands of colonists arrived from the Holy Roman Empire, Poland and other neighboring regions to settle in the depopulated lands.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Béla's efforts to rebuild his devastated country won him the epithet of "second founder of the state" .

title: Béla IV of Hungary

title: Béla IV of Hungary

title: Béla IV of Hungary

title: Béla IV of Hungary

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: He was forced to cede the territories of the Kingdom of Hungary east of the river Danube to Stephen, which caused a civil war lasting until 1266.

title: Béla IV of Hungary
text: Nevertheless, Béla's family was famed for his piety: he died as a Franciscan tertiary, and the veneration of his three saintly daughtersKunigunda, Yolanda, and Margaretwas confirmed by the Holy See.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.

title: Place of birth
text: This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.

title: Place of birth
text: As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.

title: Place of birth
text: If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.

title: Place of birth
text: For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.

title: Place of birth
text: This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.

title: Place of birth
text: Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.

title: Place of birth
text: In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".

title: Place of birth
text: Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").

title: Place of birth
text: There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).

title: Place of birth
text: Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".

title: Place of birth
text: It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".

title: Place of birth
text: For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

title: Frank Zappa
text: Frank Vincent Zappa (December 21, 1940 – December 4, 1993) was an American multi-instrumentalist musician, composer, and bandleader.

title: Frank Zappa
text: His work is characterized by nonconformity, free-form improvisation, sound experiments, musical virtuosity, and satire of American culture.

title: Frank Zappa
text: In a career spanning more than 30 years, Zappa composed rock, pop, jazz, jazz fusion, orchestral and "musique concrète" works, and produced almost all of the 60-plus albums that he released with his band the Mothers of Invention and as a solo artist.

title: Frank Zappa
text: Zappa also directed feature-length films and music videos, and designed album covers.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He is considered one of the most innovative and stylistically diverse rock musicians of his era.

title: Frank Zappa
text: As a self-taught composer and performer, Zappa's diverse musical influences led him to create music that was sometimes difficult to categorize.

title: Frank Zappa
text: While in his teens, he acquired a taste for 20th-century classical modernism, African-American rhythm and blues, and doo-wop music.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He began writing classical music in high school, while at the same time playing drums in rhythm and blues bands, later switching to electric guitar.

title: Frank Zappa
text: His 1966 debut album with the Mothers of Invention, "Freak Out!", combined songs in conventional rock and roll format with collective improvisations and studio-generated sound collages.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He continued this eclectic and experimental approach, irrespective of whether the fundamental format was rock, jazz or classical.

title: Frank Zappa
text: Zappa's output is unified by a conceptual continuity he termed "Project/Object", with numerous musical phrases, ideas, and characters reappearing across his albums.

title: Frank Zappa
text: His lyrics reflected his iconoclastic views of established social and political processes, structures and movements, often humorously so, and he has been described as the "godfather" of comedy rock.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He was a strident critic of mainstream education and organized religion, and a forthright and passionate advocate for freedom of speech, self-education, political participation and the abolition of censorship.

title: Frank Zappa
text: Unlike many other rock musicians of his generation, he personally disapproved of drugs, but supported their decriminalization and regulation.

title: Frank Zappa
text: During Zappa's lifetime, he was a highly productive and prolific artist with a controversial critical standing; supporters of his music admired its compositional complexity, while critics found it lacking emotional depth.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He had some commercial success, particularly in Europe, and worked as an independent artist for most of his career.

title: Frank Zappa
text: He remains a major influence on musicians and composers.

title: Frank Zappa
text: His honors include his 1995 induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the 1997 Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award.

title: Frank Zappa
text: In 2000, he was ranked number 36 on VH1's "100 Greatest Artists of Hard Rock".

title: Frank Zappa
text: In 2004, "Rolling Stone" magazine ranked him at number 71 on its list of the "100 Greatest Artists of All Time", and in 2011 at number 22 on its list of the "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time".

title: Jim Wynorski
text: His earliest films were released to movie theaters, but his later works have predominantly been released to cable or the straight- to- video market.

title: Jim Wynorski
text: He often works under pseudonyms such as" Jay Andrews, Arch Stanton, H.R.

title: Jim Wynorski
text: Blueberry, Tom Popatopolis," and" Noble Henry."

title: Jim Wynorski
text: His movies often spoof horror films:" Cleavagefield", for example, parodies" Cloverfield The Bare Wench Project" parodies" The Blair Witch Project", and" Para- Knockers Activity" parodies" Paranormal Activity".

title: Jim Wynorski
text: A character in the film" The Final Destination" is named after him.

title: Jim Wynorski
text: In 2009, the documentary" Popatopolis", directed by Clay Westervelt and named for one of Wynorski's pseudonyms, chronicled Wynorski during the making of his soft- core horror film," The Witches of Breastwick".

title: Jim Wynorski
text: The film serves as a partial biography, with clips from many of his previous films and includes interviews with Wynorski, his contemporaries, cast, and crew.

title: Jim Wynorski
text: In 2016, he directed" Nessie& Me", marking the first time that he directed a children's film.

title: Jim Wynorski
text: The character Jack O’ Grady directly references Wynorski's earlier films" Dinocroc vs. Supergator" and" Piranhaconda" when he encounters Nessie at the start of the film, hinting that" Nessie& Me" is canon to those film series, as well as" Monster Cruise", with many characters from it appearing in" Nessie& Me" as well.

title: Sorority House Massacre II
text: Sorority House Massacre

title: Sorority House Massacre II
text: II: Nighty Nightmare is a 1990 American slasher film directed by Jim Wynorski, featuring scream queens Melissa Ann Moore and Gail Harris( credited as Robyn Harris).

title: Sorority House Massacre II
text: Much like its predecessors," Sorority House Massacre II" has received a cult following over the years.

title: Sorority House Massacre II
text: It is a loose sequel to" Sorority House Massacre", as well as" Slumber Party Massacre", from which it recycles some footage.

title: Sorority House Massacre
text: Sorority House Massacre is a 1987 American slasher film directed and written by Carol Frank.

title: Sorority House Massacre
text: The plot follows a potential sorority pledge who experiences deja vu regarding the sorority house she's visiting, followed by a murderer who begins killing the sorority residents over Memorial Day weekend.

title: Sorority House Massacre
text: The film is in the same realm as" Slumber Party Massacre" series, and was marketed as part of the" Massacre Collection".

title: Sorority House Massacre
text: A loose sequel," Sorority House Massacre II", was released four years later.

title: Sorority House Massacre
text: Despite the largely negative reception( often criticized for being" too similar" to" Halloween"), the film has gained a small cult following over the years among fans of the slasher genre.

title: Lucas Demare
text: Lucas Demare (July 14, 1910 – September 6, 1981) was an Argentine film director, screenwriter and film producer prominent in the Cinema of Argentina in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s.

title: Lucas Demare
text: At the 1943 Argentine Film Critics Association Awards, Demare won Silver Condor awards for Best Director, Best Film and numerous other awards for "The Gaucho War" (1942), a film which is considered by critics in Argentina to be one of the best films in its history.

title: Lucas Demare
text: He won further awards including Best Film and Director for "Su mejor alumno" (1944) at the 1945 Argentine Film Critics Association Awards.

title: Lucas Demare
text: He wrote and directed other films such as "El cura gaucho" (1941), "La calle grita" (1948), "Mi noche triste" (1951), "Zafra" (1958) and "La Boda" (1964).

title: Lucas Demare
text: His last film as a director was "Hombres de mar" in 1977.

title: Lucas Demare
text: In 1964, he was a member of the jury at the 14th Berlin International Film Festival.

title: Lucas Demare
text: He died of a heart attack at the age of 71 in 1981.

title: Lucas Demare
text: His brother was the composer Lucio Demare who wrote several film scores for Lucas' productions.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: Chicago 10: Speak Your Peace is a 2007 American animated documentary written and directed by Brett Morgen that tells the story of the Chicago Eight.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: The film features the voices of Hank Azaria, Dylan Baker, Nick Nolte, Mark Ruffalo, Roy Scheider, Liev Schreiber, James Urbaniak, and Jeffrey Wright in an animated reenactment of the trial based on transcripts and rediscovered audio recordings.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: It also contains archival footage of Abbie Hoffman, David Dellinger, William Kunstler, Jerry Rubin, Bobby Seale, Tom Hayden, and Leonard Weinglass, and of the protest and riot itself.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: The title is drawn from a quote by Rubin, who said," Anyone who calls us the Chicago Seven is a racist.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: Because you're discrediting Bobby Seale.

title: Chicago 10 (film)
text: You can call us the Chicago Eight, but really we're the Chicago Ten, because our two lawyers went down with us."

text: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri (née Francart, c.1817–1878) was an early French photographer.

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri

text: After her husband left for Paris in 1852, Geneviève continued to run the atelier alone.

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri
text: She is remembered for her 28 views of Brest, mainly architectural, which were published as "Brest

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri
text: et ses Environs" in 1856.

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri
text: In 1872, she moved to Paris, opening a studio in the Rue du Bac where she was possibly assisted by her son Jules.

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri
text: Trade listings indicate she continued to operate her studio until her death in a Paris hospital in 1878.

title: Geneviève Élisabeth Disdéri
text: She was one of the first female professional photographers in the world, active only shortly after Bertha Beckmann and Brita Sofia Hesselius.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: George of York, 1st Duke of Bedford( March 1477 – March 1479) was the eighth child and third son of Edward IV of England and Elizabeth Woodville.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: He was a younger brother of Elizabeth of York, Mary of York, Cecily of York, Edward V of England, Margaret Plantagenet, Richard of Shrewsbury, 1st Duke of York and Anne of York.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: He was also an older brother of Catherine of York and Bridget of York.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: He was born in Windsor Castle in March 1477, and was created Duke of Bedford in infancy, probably in 1478, after the former holder of the title, George Neville, was deprived of the title by act of Parliament, ostensibly for lack of money to maintain the style of a duke.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: He was appointed the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland in 1478, one of a series of nominal and largely absent lieutenants.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: George died aged two.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: This is considered likely to have been due to an outbreak of bubonic plague.

title: George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford
text: He was buried in St George's Chapel at Windsor Castle on March 22, 1479.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Edward IV (28 April 1442 – 9 April 1483) was King of England from 4 March 1461 to 3 October 1470, and again from 11 April 1471 until his death.

title: Edward IV of England
text: His father, Richard of York, leader of the Yorkist faction, was a lineal descendant of Edward III and until 1453, heir presumptive to Henry VI, from the ruling House of Lancaster, or Lancastrians.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Less than a year old when he came to the throne in September 1422

title: Edward IV of England
text: , Henry's minority was marked by political infighting within the Regency council.

title: Edward IV of England
text: After 1437, he ruled in his own right but his weak and indecisive personality did little to mitigate factional conflict.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Shortly after the birth of his son Edward of Westminster in 1453, Henry suffered a complete mental breakdown and the government descended into chaos.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Conflict between Yorkists and Lancastrians led to civil war in 1455.

title: Edward IV of England
text: This continued intermittently until 1485 and is collectively known as The Wars of the Roses.

title: Edward IV of England
text: After Richard was executed in December 1460, Edward became head of the family; with the support of the Earl of Warwick, or 'The Kingmaker', he deposed Henry and was crowned king in June 1461.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Divisions developed after Edward's marriage to Elizabeth Woodville in 1464; Warwick switched sides in 1470 and restored Henry to the throne.

title: Edward IV of England
text: Edward fled to Flanders, but returned to England in March 1471, winning victories at Barnet in April and Tewkesbury in

title: Edward IV of England
text: May. Warwick, Henry's heir Edward of Westminster and other senior Lancastrians were killed, while Henry died in the Tower of London a few days later.

title: Edward IV of England
text: England remained relatively peaceful until Edward's death in 1483.

title: Edward IV of England
text: His two minor sons, Edward and Richard were subsequently declared illegitimate by his younger brother, the Duke of Gloucester, who became Richard III.

title: Christopher Topham
text: Christopher Topham, member of Parliament for York( died 1670), was the son of York merchant and Sheriff for the city of York Christopher Topham and his wife Ann, a daughter of Percival Levett, merchant of York and also formerly a Sheriff for the city of York.

title: Christopher Topham
text: Topham was married to Susan Micklethwait, daughter of Elias Micklethwait, York merchant and member of Parliament as well as twice the mayor of York.

title: Christopher Topham

title: Christopher Topham

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: Margaret of York( 10 April 1472 – 11 December 1472) was a namesake niece of Margaret of York, Duchess of Burgundy.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: She was the fifth child and fourth daughter of Edward IV of England and Elizabeth Woodville.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: She was a younger sister of Elizabeth of York, Mary of York, Cecily of York and Edward V of England and older sister of Richard of Shrewsbury, 1st Duke of York, Anne of York, George Plantagenet, Duke of Bedford, Catherine of York and Bridget of York.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: She was born in Winchester Castle but died of natural causes eight months later.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: She was buried in Westminster Abbey.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: Margaret's sarcophagus was originally placed to fit in the steps of the shrine of St. Edward the Confessor, but it was moved to the edge of the chapel at the time of the dissolution of the monasteries.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: The step edging around the sides can, however, still be seen.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: An annotated history of the Abbey in the Abbey's library states that the lid was removed in more modern times and the sarcophagus found to be empty.

title: Margaret of York (1472)
text: The monumental brass originally on the top of Margaret's tomb is long since missing, but the original wording around the edge and on the surface plaque was recorded historically.

title: Bridget of York
text: Bridget of York( 10 November 1480 – 1517) was an English princess, the tenth child and seventh daughter of Edward IV of England and Queen Elizabeth Woodville.

title: Bridget of York
text: She was the youngest sister of Elizabeth of York, Mary of York, Cecily of York, Edward V, Margaret of York, Richard of Shrewsbury, 1st Duke of York, Anne of York, George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Bedford, and Catherine of York.

title: Bridget of York
text: She was also an aunt of Henry VIII of England.

title: Bridget of York
text: She was born in Eltham, London on 10 November 1480, and was baptised by Edward Story, Bishop of Chichester on 11 November 1480.

title: Bridget of York
text: Her godmothers at the baptismal fount were her paternal grandmother, Cecily Neville, Duchess of York, and her oldest sister, Elizabeth of York.

title: Bridget of York
text: Her godfather was William Waynflete, Bishop of Winchester.

title: Bridget of York
text: Bridget's aunt Margaret, Lady Maltravers, served as her godmother at her confirmation.

title: Bridget of York
text: Bridget was likely named after St. Bridget of Sweden.

title: Bridget of York
text: Her parents may have decided at the time of her birth that this daughter would be dedicated to a religious life, and Princess Bridget was entrusted to Dartford Priory, Dartford, Kent sometime between 1486 and 1492.

title: Bridget of York
text: She became a nun.

title: Bridget of York
text: Bridget maintained correspondence throughout her life with her sister Elizabeth of York, who also paid for her various minor expenses, as well as minor expenses of the orphaned Agnes of Eltham.

title: Bridget of York
text: After Bridget's sister, Elizabeth of York, married Henry VII, Elizabeth paid some of Bridget's expenses and kept in touch with her via messengers.

title: Bridget of York
text: Bridget is known to have left Dartford on at least one occasion, when she attended the funeral of her mother, Elizabeth Woodville, in 1492.

title: Bridget of York
text: She died about 1517.

title: Kristi Lee
text: Kristi Lee is the news director of the nationally syndicated radio show" The Bob& Tom Show" and is responsible for delivering newscasts of various headlines( which are often used for humorous takeoffs) during the show.

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee often hosted or participated in shows..

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee graduated from Ben Davis High School in Indianapolis and got her start on WBDG, the school's station.

title: Kristi Lee
text: She attended Indiana University.

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee's first full- time job in communications was at WRTV, where she was a television engineer for six years.

title: Kristi Lee
text: At the time, she was also a part- time disc jockey for WFBQ Q95, the station which eventually hired Bob Kevoian and Tom Griswold for mornings.

title: Kristi Lee
text: She began her full- time radio career on" The Bob and Tom Show" in 1988.

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee was also featured on ESPN and ESPN2 as a sideline reporter, covering events like lacrosse, auto racing, and the first three X Games on ESPN2.

title: Kristi Lee
text: In the mid-nineties, she was the sideline reporter for the NBA's Indiana Pacers.

title: Kristi Lee
text: On January 11, 2016, Lee announced that she was leaving" The Bob and Tom Show."

title: Kristi Lee
text: Prior to her later return, Lee's last" on air" appearance was on December 17, 2015.

title: Kristi Lee
text: In an April 2016 appearance on the" Hammer and Nigel" podcast, Lee revealed that her" Bob and Tom" contract had been" rolling over for 12 years" and included a three- month non-compete clause, a length brief enough as to be considered" unheard of in our business."

title: Kristi Lee
text: Since any new contract would likely have extended her non-compete requirement to six or 12 months, Lee said she chose not to renew her contract.

title: Kristi Lee
text: It was" time to try something different," Lee said.

title: Kristi Lee
text: " If I'm going to do this, it's going to have to be now."

title: Kristi Lee
text: The announcement and timing of Kevoian's December 2015 retirement was a surprise to Lee, and she told the" Dan Dakich Show" that" Bob was n't there, and I did n't want to sit in that room without Bobby" despite her continued fondness for Griswold and Chick McGee, the show's remaining longtime stars.

title: Kristi Lee
text: On July 8, 2016," The Bob and Tom Show" announced that Lee would return to the show on July 11, 2016.

title: Kristi Lee
text: In an interview with" BoomerTV's"

title: Kristi Lee
text: Patty Spitler, Lee reiterated that a desire to find her own voice as an interviewer and to create her" own brand" were her primary motivations for what ended up being a hiatus from" The Bob and Tom Show."

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee also said Griswold initiated the discussions which led to her return.

title: Kristi Lee
text: During her six- month break from" Bob and Tom", Lee began hosting a podcast titled" Kristi Lee Uninterrupted," which debuted on April 5, 2016.

title: Kristi Lee
text: The podcast is affiliated with Dr. Will's Neighborhood.

title: Kristi Lee
text: It s title is a reference to Griswold's habit of constantly interrupting her" Bob and Tom Show" news reports.

title: Kristi Lee
text: Lee announced that she will continue to produce her podcast.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Little Man was the son of Stone Forehead's sister and thus the cousin of Black Hairy Dog.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: At the latter's death, circa. 1883, Little Man succeeded him as Keeper.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: His father Turtle Following His Wife and his mother Running Face along with his brother White Beaver.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Like his family of the arrows he too possessed Spirit Lodge power to an unusual degree.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Little Man, Keeper of the Arrows reigned during a time when the Cheyenne was in build.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: He was considered a traditionalist, and opposed the Indian Agent on a regular basis.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: In 1901, the agent threatened to cut off rations if Little Man did not send the children to the Indian schools.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: In 1914, he attempted to turn the Keeper's responsibility over to Old Crow.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: The transfer was refused by the Chiefs, the Arrow priest and the leaders of the military societies.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: They held fast to Sweet Medicine's rule that the Arrow Keeper must be Tsistsistas, but on request Little Man permitted peyote to be placed in the Sacred Arrow Bundle, soon died in 1917.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Thus silencing decades of loyalty, generations of guardianship and centuries of keepers of his royal bloodline.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Guardians and Priests of the Arrows soon shifted to a new Keeper, but an unlikely era.

title: Little Man (Cheyenne Arrow Keeper)
text: Little Man's sons to young to take leadership, soon taken away by the white man.

title: Hans Fallada
text: Hans Fallada( born Rudolf Wilhelm Friedrich Ditzen; 21 July 18935 February 1947) was a German writer of the first half of the 20th century.

title: Hans Fallada
text: Some of his better known novels include" Little Man, What Now?"( 1932) and" Every Man Dies Alone"( 1947).

title: Hans Fallada
text: His works belong predominantly to the New Objectivity literary style, a style associated with an emotionless reportage approach, with precision of detail, and a veneration for' the fact'.

title: Hans Fallada
text: Fallada's pseudonym derives from a combination of characters found in the Grimm's Fairy Tales:

title: Hans Fallada
text: The titular protagonist of" Hans in Luck"( KHM 83), and Falada the magical talking horse in" The Goose Girl".
