title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: Little Man,

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: What Now? is a 1933 German drama film directed by Fritz Wendhausen and starring Hermann Thimig, Hertha Thiele and Viktor de Kowa.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: It is an adaptation of the novel of the same name by Hans Fallada.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: The original concept for the film was to take a naturalistic approach, the same way the novel did, with Kurt Weill composing the music.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: Fallada had already remarked in 1932, after falling out with the producers and script writers, that the film had little to do with his novel, and that the script writers" would take a different approach," which they did.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: The Nazi Film Review Office insisted on extensive cuts, including all scenes featuring the Comedian Harmonists.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: The film's sets were designed by the art directors Willy Schiller and Otto Guelstorff.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: Location shooting took place around Swinemünde.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: It was well received by contemporary critics, many of whom considered it the best German film of 1933.

title: Little Man, What Now? (1933 film)
text: A separate American film adaptation of Fallada's novel," Little Man, What Now?", was released in 1934.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: William Tecumseh Sherman (February 8, 1820 – February 14, 1891) was an American soldier, businessman, educator, and author.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He served as a general in the Union Army during the American Civil War (1861–65), for which he received recognition for his outstanding command of military strategy as well as criticism for the harshness of the scorched earth policies he implemented in conducting total war against the Confederate States.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman was born into a prominent political family.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1840 and was stationed in California.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He married Ellen Ewing Sherman and together they raised eight children.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman's wife and children were all devout Catholics, while Sherman was originally a member of the faith but later left it.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: In 1859, he gained a position as superintendent of the Louisiana State Seminary of Learning & Military Academy.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Living in the South, Sherman grew to respect Southern culture and sympathize with the practice of Southern slavery, although he opposed secession.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman began his Civil War career serving with distinction in the First Battle of Bull Run before being transferred to the Western Theater.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He served in Kentucky in 1861, where he acted overly paranoid, exaggerating the presence of spies in the region and providing what seemed to be alarmingly high estimates of the number of troops needed to pacify Kentucky.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He was granted leave, and fell into depression.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman returned to serve under General Ulysses S. Grant in the winter of 1862 during the battles of forts Henry and Donelson.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Before the Battle of Shiloh, Sherman commanded a division.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Failing to make proper preparations for a Confederate offensive, his men were surprised and overrun.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He later rallied his division and helped drive the Confederates back.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman later served in the Siege of Corinth and commanded the XV Corps during the Vicksburg Campaign, which led to the fall of the critical Confederate stronghold of Vicksburg on the Mississippi River.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: After Grant was promoted to command of all Western armies, Sherman took over the Army of the Tennessee and led it during the Chattanooga Campaign, which culminated with the routing of the Confederate armies in the state of Tennessee.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: In 1864, Sherman succeeded Grant as the Union commander in the western theater of the war.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He proceeded to lead his troops to the capture of the city of Atlanta, a military success that contributed to the re-election of Abraham Lincoln.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman's subsequent march through Georgia and the Carolinas further undermined the Confederacy's ability to continue fighting by destroying large amounts of supplies and demoralizing the Southern people.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: The tactics that he used during this march, though effective, remain a subject of controversy.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He accepted the surrender of all the Confederate armies in the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida in April 1865, after having been present at most major military engagements in the West.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: When Grant assumed the U.S. presidency in 1869, Sherman succeeded him as Commanding General of the Army, in which capacity he served from 1869 until 1883.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: As such, he was responsible for the U.S. Army's engagement in the Indian Wars over the next 15 years.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman advocated total war against hostile Indians to force them back onto their reservations.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: He was skeptical of the Reconstruction era policies of the federal government in the South.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: Sherman steadfastly refused to be drawn into politics and in 1875 published his "Memoirs", one of the best-known first-hand accounts of the Civil War.

title: William Tecumseh Sherman
text: British military historian B. H. Liddell Hart declared that Sherman was "the first modern general."

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lee Jun-fan (November 27, 1940 – July 20, 1973), known professionally as Bruce Lee , was a Hong Kong-American actor, director, martial artist, martial arts instructor, and philosopher.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He was the founder of Jeet Kune Do, a hybrid martial arts philosophy drawing from different combat disciplines that is often credited with paving the way for modern mixed martial arts (MMA).

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lee is considered by commentators, critics, media, and other martial artists to be the most influential martial artist of all time and a pop culture icon of the 20th century, who bridged the gap between East and West.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He is often credited with helping to change the way Asians were presented in American films.

title: Bruce Lee
text: The son of Cantonese opera star Lee Hoi-chuen, Lee was born in the Chinatown area of San Francisco, California on November 27, 1940 to parents from Hong Kong, and was raised with his family in Kowloon, Hong Kong.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He was introduced to the film industry by his father and appeared in several films as a child actor.

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lee moved to the United States at the age of 18 to receive his higher education at the University of Washington in Seattle, and it was during this time that he began teaching martial arts.

title: Bruce Lee
text: His Hong Kong and Hollywood-produced films elevated the traditional Hong Kong martial arts film to a new level of popularity and acclaim, sparking a surge of interest in Chinese martial arts in the West in the 1970s.

title: Bruce Lee
text: The direction and tone of his films dramatically changed and influenced martial arts and martial arts films in the Hollywood, Hong Kong, and the rest of the world.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He is noted for his roles in five feature-length martial arts films in the early 1970s:

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lo Wei's "The Big Boss" (1971) and "Fist of Fury" (1972); Golden Harvest's "Way of the Dragon" (1972), directed and written by Lee;

title: Bruce Lee
text: Golden Harvest and Warner Brothers' "Enter the Dragon" (1973) and

title: Bruce Lee
text: "The Game of Death" (1978), both directed by Robert Clouse.

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lee became an iconic figure known throughout the world, particularly among the Chinese, based upon his portrayal of Chinese nationalism in his films and among Asian Americans for defying stereotypes associated with the emasculated Asian male.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He trained in the art of Wing Chun and later combined his other influences from various sources into the spirit of his personal martial arts philosophy, which he dubbed Jeet Kune Do (The Way of the Intercepting Fist).

title: Bruce Lee
text: Lee had residences in Hong Kong and Seattle.

title: Bruce Lee
text: He died on July 20, 1973 at the age of 32.

text: Weinstein won an Academy Award for producing "Shakespeare in Love", and garnered seven Tony Awards for a variety of plays and musicals, including "The ProducersBilly Elliot the Musical", and .

text: He was co-chairman, alongside Bob, from 2005 to 2017.

title: Harvey Weinstein
text: In October 2017, following sexual abuse allegations against Weinstein, he was dismissed from his company and expelled from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Harvey Weinstein
text: By October 31, over 80 women had made allegations against Weinstein.

title: Harvey Weinstein
text: The allegations sparked the #MeToo social media campaign and many similar sexual abuse allegations against and dismissals of powerful men around the world, now called the "Weinstein effect".

title: Harvey Weinstein
text: On May 25, 2018, Weinstein was arrested in New York, charged with rape and other offenses, and released on bail.

title: Khalid al-Habib
text: Khalid al- Habib also believed to use the nom de guerre Khalid al Harbi is an Al- Qaeda leader who has overseen Al- Qaeda operations in Afghanistan.

title: Khalid al-Habib
text: In 2005 it was reported that al- Habib died in a US missile strike on the Pakistani village of Damadola though it is unclear whether this is the case as Pakistani officials have claimed that no Al- Qaeda leaders died in the attack.

title: Khalid al-Habib
text: al- Habib's nationality is not clear with sources claiming he may be Egyptian or Moroccan.

title: Horsetooth Mountain

title: Horsetooth Mountain

title: Wayra Q'asa (Angaraes)
text: Wayra Q'asa( Quechua" wayra" wind," q'asa" mountain pass," wind pass", Hispanicized spelling" Huayraccasa") is a mountain in the Andes of Peru, about high.

text: It is situated in the Huancavelica Region, Angaraes Province, Lircay District.

title: Wayra Q'asa (Angaraes)
text: Wayra Q'asa lies southwest of Hatun Rit'i, northwest of Qiwllaqucha and northeast of Puka Q'asa.

title: Chawpi Urqu (Cangallo)
text: Chawpi Urqu( Quechua" chawpi" middle, center," urqu" mountain," middle mountain", Hispanicized spelling" Chaupi Orjo") is a mountain in the Andes of Peru, about high.

title: Chawpi Urqu (Cangallo)
text: It is situated in the Ayacucho Region, Cangallo Province, Totos District, northeast of Totos.

title: Chawpi Urqu (Cangallo)
text: Chawpi Urqu lies north of Huch'uy Puka Q'asa.

title: Chawpi Urqu (Cangallo)
text: The lake east of it is named Llulluchaqucha"( Llullucha Ccocha)".

title: Puka Q'asa (Huaytará)
text: Puka Q'asa( Quechua" puka" red," q'asa" mountain pass," red mountain pass", also spelled" Pucaccasa") is a mountain in the Huancavelica Region in Peru, about high.

title: Puka Q'asa (Huaytará)
text: It is located in the Huaytará Province, Pilpichaca District.

title: Puka Q'asa (Huaytará)
text: Puka Q'asa lies southwest of a mountain named Yawarqucha, east of Chuqlluqucha.

title: Puka Q'asa (Huaytará)
text: The little lake northwest of Puka Q'asa is Wachwaqucha(" Andean goose lake").

title: Puka Q'asa (Angaraes)
text: Puka Q'asa( Quechua" puka" red," q'asa" mountain pass," red mountain pass", Hispanicized spelling" Pucaccasa") is a mountain in the Andes of Peru, about high.

text: It is situated in the Huancavelica Region, Angaraes Province, Lircay District.

title: Puka Q'asa (Angaraes)

title: Puka Q'asa (Castrovirreyna-Huancavelica)
text: Puka Q'asa( Quechua" puka" red," q'asa" mountain pass," red mountain pass", hispanicized spelling" Pucajasa") is a mountain in the Chunta mountain range in the Andes of Peru, about high.

title: Puka Q'asa (Castrovirreyna-Huancavelica)
text: It lies in the Huancavelica Region, Castrovirreyna Province, Castrovirreyna District, and in the Huancavelica Province, Huancavelica District.

title: Puka Q'asa (Castrovirreyna-Huancavelica)
text: Puka Q'asa lies at the Yuraq Ranra valley west of Wachu Intiyuq.

title: Puka Q'asa (Castrovirreyna-Huancavelica)
text: Its intermittent stream flows to the Kachimayu in the north.

title: Kiswara
text: Kiswara( Aymara for" Buddleja incana", hispanicized spelling" Quisuara") is a mountain in the Andes of Peru, about high.

title: Huch'uy Puka Q'asa

title: Huch'uy Puka Q'asa
text: ( Quechua “ huch'uy ” little, “ puka ” red, “ q'asa ” mountain pass, meaning “ little red pass ”, also spelled “ Uchuy Pucaccasa ”) is a mountain in the Andes of Peru, about high.

text: It is situated in the Ayacucho Region, Cangallo Province, Totos District, northeast of Totos.

text: Huch'uy Puka Q'asa lies south of Chawpi Urqu.

title: Puka Q'asa (Huancavelica)
text: Puka Q'asa( Quechua" puka" red," q'asa" mountain pass," red mountain pass", Hispanicized spelling" Pucajasa") is a mountain in the Chunta mountain range in the Andes of Peru, about high.

title: Puka Q'asa (Huancavelica)

title: Puka Q'asa (Huancavelica)
text: Puka Q'asa lies northeast of Q'iru Pinqullu and Winchu Q'asa, and east of Tipiqucha.

title: Winchu Q'asa
text: Winchu Q'asa( Quechua" winchu" magnetite," q'asa" mountain pass," magnetite pass", Hispanicized spelling" Huinchujasa") is a mountain in the Chunta in the Andes of Peru, about high.

title: Winchu Q'asa

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The other current books in the" What is?" series include

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Love?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Death?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Beautiful?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Funny?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Right?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Peace?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Money?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is Dreaming?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Friend?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is True?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Family?,

title: Etan Boritzer
text: What is a Feeling?"

title: Etan Boritzer
text: The series is now also translated into 15 languages.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

title: Lesley Selander
text: Lesley Selander (May 26, 1900 – December 5, 1979) was an American film director of Westerns and adventure movies.

title: Lesley Selander
text: His career as director, spanning 127 feature films and dozens of TV episodes, lasted from 1936-68.

title: Lesley Selander
text: Before that, Selander was assistant director on films such as "The Cat and the Fiddle" (1934), "A Night at the Opera" (1935), and Fritz Lang's "Fury" (1936).

title: Lesley Selander
text: To this day Selander remains one of the most prolific directors of feature Westerns in cinema history, having taken the helm for 107 Westerns between his first directorial feature in 1936 and 1967.

title: Lesley Selander
text: In 1956 he was nominated for the Directors Guild of America award for Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Television, for his work directing a 1954 episode of "Lassie".

title: Are All Men Pedophiles?
text: Are All Men Pedophiles?

title: Are All Men Pedophiles?
text: is a 2012 documentary film by Rwandan- Dutch media producer Jan-Willem Breure.

title: Are All Men Pedophiles?
text: Presented by 14- year- old model Savannah van Zweeden and covering the topics of pedophilia and hebephilia, the entire film was financed privately, mainly by the 23- year- old Breure( with the rest of the funding coming from the Royal Academy of Art, The Hague).

title: Are All Men Pedophiles?
text: " Are All Men Pedophiles?" had its world premiere at the Queens World Film Festival in New York City on March 2, 2012 and has been screened at a number of film festivals.
